question_details.title: Will Doge's Agency Efficiency Leaderboard have the Department of State ranked highest in Least Total Savings on April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: The American Conservative: [The Inside Story of DOGE’s State Department Reforms](https://www.theamericanconservative.com/the-inside-story-of-doges-state-department-reforms/)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Department of Government Efficiency's Agency Efficiency Leaderboard has the Department of State ranked highest in Least Total Savings at [this link](https://doge.gov/savings) when checked by Metaculus on or after April 1, 2025.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**DOGE claims cuts have saved whopping $115B, or around $700 per taxpayer**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) claims that its efforts to cut waste, fraud, and abuse in the federal government have resulted in $115 billion in savings. According to DOGE, this translates to an average of $714.29 per taxpayer, based on 2022 figures. However, using the latest tax return year of 2023, the average saved per taxpayer would be $705.09. DOGE says the biggest savings have come from the General Services Administration (GSA), followed by the Education Department and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The agency has terminated over 5,350 contracts, worth around $20 billion, and nearly 7,500 grants, worth $17 billion. Additionally, nearly 800 leases have been canceled, resulting in $500 million in lease savings. DOGE was created by President Donald Trump and will operate until July 4, 2026. 'It is unclear exactly where the bulk of the GSA cuts emanate from,' the article notes. DOGE has faced criticism over its access to federal systems and its efforts to cancel federal contracts and make cuts at various agencies.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 05:15 PM
Source:[Fox Business](https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/doge-claims-cuts-have-saved-whopping-115b-around-700-per-taxpayer)

**DOGE's latest savings claims "seem overstated," BofA analysts say By Investing.com**
Analysts at BofA have questioned the Department of Government Efficiency's (DOGE) latest claim of saving $20 billion through federal contract cancellations and renegotiations, stating that the figure 'seems overstated.' According to BofA, the actual savings are around $18 billion, but the analysts have concerns about DOGE's methodology, which they believe could be misleading. They also identified 'some cases' of double counting in the elimination of contracts and subcontracts. BofA analysts led by Mariana Perez Mora noted that the U.S. Agency for International Development and the Treasury Department were the most heavily impacted agencies, while General Dynamics and Booz Allen Hamilton received significant reductions in funding.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 12:06 PM
Source:[Investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/economy-news/doges-latest-savings-claims-seem-overstated-bofa-analysts-say-3929403)

**'Doge' Measures: Hundreds of US Government Offices Could Close**
Elon Musk's 'Department of government efficiency', also known as 'Doge', plans to terminate hundreds of US government office leases, citing unnecessary state expenses. According to internal documents, over 800 leases will be canceled, with many set to expire by June 30. This move is expected to save around $500 million, although this figure does not account for the costs of relocation and closure. Musk's team has been prioritizing leases that can be terminated without penalty within a few months. The decision has sparked appeals from various US agencies and lawmakers to exempt certain buildings from the measure. 'Doge' has informed landlords of its plans, with the goal of reducing unnecessary expenses. As Musk stated, 'Doge' will continue to target 'unnecessary state expenses'.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 14, 2025 10:53 AM
Source:[Euronews Deutsch](https://de.euronews.com/2025/03/14/nach-doge-massnahmen-hunderte-von-us-bundesamtern-konnten-bald-schliessen)

**Elon Musk's DOGE: A Mixed Bag on Budget Cuts?**
Elon Musk's Department of Efficiency (DOGE) has been tasked with reducing the US federal deficit by $1 trillion. However, the results of their efforts are not yet clear. According to the US Treasury, the country's federal spending in February 2025 was actually higher than in February 2024, at $603 billion compared to $567 billion. Analyst Jessica Riedl notes that the savings made by the DOGE are 'too small to be identifiable in the total monthly spending figures' for each ministry. The DOGE has focused on cutting budgets for smaller ministries, such as education and the environment, but has not yet touched the larger areas of spending, such as defense and social security. The agency has announced plans to reduce staff at NASA, and it is unclear which ministries will be next to face budget cuts.
Original language: fr
Publish date: March 14, 2025 05:32 AM
Source:[LExpress.fr](https://www.lexpress.fr/economie/coupes-budgetaires-aux-etats-unis-le-doge-delon-musk-pas-si-efficace-OPVZ4B72INHZZIG4KN3QTXAO4A/)

**States Most Affected by DOGE Cuts: A Report by WalletHub**
The Department of Efficiency Government (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, aims to reduce the federal government's spending of $1 billion this year by firing workers, canceling contracts, and cutting budgets across all areas. According to a report, the states with the highest federal dependence will be most affected by these cuts. The report analyzed data to determine the federal dependence of both state governments and residents, considering tax revenue, federal employment, and federal funding as a percentage of state income. Chip Lupo of WalletHub stated, 'Regardless of whether the distribution of federal funds is fair or not, living in one of the states with the highest federal dependence can be beneficial for residents.' He added, 'For every dollar residents of these states pay in taxes, they receive several dollars back in federal funds, which often translates to better infrastructure, education, and public health, among other benefits.' 
Original language: es
Publish date: March 14, 2025 03:12 AM
Source:[as](https://as.com/us/actualidad/atencion-si-vives-en-uno-de-estos-5-estados-estos-son-los-que-mas-sufriran-los-recortes-del-doge-de-elon-musk-n/)

**DOGE obscures details of savings after posting error-filled data on its website**
Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has been accused of obscuring details of its savings after posting error-filled data on its website. The agency, which was created to promote transparency, has removed identifying information from its website, making it impossible for independent organizations to fact-check their savings claims. This move comes after a federal judge ruled that DOGE must comply with public transparency laws due to its 'unprecedented' authority and 'unusual secrecy.' The White House has argued that DOGE's records should be protected until at least 2034, despite Musk's previous calls for 'maximum transparency.' The agency's savings goals have also been questioned, with some reports suggesting that firing every federal worker outside the military or USPS would only save $245.8 billion a year, a far cry from Musk's promised goal of saving $1 trillion.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 13, 2025 09:12 PM
Source:[The Independent](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/musk-doge-savings-data-errors-report-b2714827.html)

**DOGE adds to Wall of Savings: here's where it claims it will save money in Michigan**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has released its weekly update to the 'Wall of Receipts,' claiming to have saved the government money by cancelling grants and contracts, as well as terminating leases for the National Park Service and other agencies. The agency claims to have saved $9.3 million and $7.9 million by terminating leases in Charles Town, West Virginia and Moab, Utah, respectively. Musk stated in an interview with Fox News that DOGE employees are in nearly every government department and could double its staff over the next year. President Donald Trump praised Musk's efforts with DOGE and acknowledged him as the head of the agency, saying, 'I have created the brand-new Department of Government Efficiency, DOGE, perhaps you've heard of it, which is headed by Elon Musk, who is in the gallery tonight.'
Original language: en
Publish date: March 13, 2025 07:15 PM
Source:[mlive](https://www.mlive.com/news/2025/03/doge-adds-to-wall-of-savings-heres-where-it-claims-it-will-save-money-in-michigan.html)

**DOGE Fails to Meet Goal of Reducing US Federal Spending**
Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) did not meet its goal of reducing US federal spending by $603 billion in February, according to the US Treasury Department's data cited by Financial Times. DOGE claimed that it had reduced spending by over $100 billion in the first month, but actual reductions were only reported in a few departments. The largest reduction was in the Education Ministry, where 6 billion dollars was saved by dismissing a significant portion of employees. Overall, state spending increased by 40 billion dollars, or 7%, compared to February 2024. Musk has previously called for reducing federal spending by $1 trillion and reducing government spending by 4 billion dollars a day. Jessica Ridley, an economic policy expert at the Manhattan Institute, told FT that 'DOGE's economy is so small that it can't be detected in overall monthly spending'. The situation is not only observed in DOGE's initiatives. The US Agency for International Development (USAID) also reduced its monthly spending by 574 million dollars to 226 million dollars, according to an audit by State Comptroller Marco Rubino. However, these reductions are insignificant compared to the additional 5 billion dollars added to the budget for healthcare and social spending (plus 8 billion dollars).
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 13, 2025 05:56 PM
Source:[Газета.uz](https://www.gazeta.uz/uz/2025/03/13/doge/)

**Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency Fails to Meet Primary Goal**
Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has failed to meet its primary goal of reducing US government spending, which reached a record high of $603 billion in February. Despite claiming to have saved the government over $100 billion, the DOGE has only managed to reduce spending in a handful of departments, with overall spending increasing by $40 billion compared to the same period last year. The DOGE has been criticized for its handling of the budget, with a judge ordering the government to rehire thousands of employees who were fired by Musk. The DOGE has also been accused of overstepping its authority and facing multiple lawsuits. Meanwhile, the US government is facing a potential shutdown if the Senate does not approve the House of Representatives' budget bill by Saturday. The bill, which was passed by the House, includes a 0.1% reduction in the federal budget, but also includes $4.5 trillion in tax cuts and a $2 trillion reduction in federal spending over the next decade, which would increase the deficit by $2.5 trillion over 10 years.
Original language: es
Publish date: March 13, 2025 02:33 PM
Source:[lavanguardia.com](https://www.lavanguardia.com/internacional/20250313/10477031/musk-logra-recortes-objetivo-principal-gasto-ee-uu-alcanzo-febrero-cifra-record.html)

**DOGE Releases 'Government Efficiency Ranking List' Claiming $65 Billion in Savings**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has released a 'Government Efficiency Ranking List' claiming to have saved $65 billion. The list ranks government institutions that have achieved the most savings through contract cancellations and other cost-cutting measures. According to DOGE, the estimated total savings amount has reached $65 billion as of Monday. Musk proudly shared the news on X, saying, 'The @DOGE department/agency ranking list shows the progress within the government, so the public can see who has made the most or least progress!' DOGE stated that the savings came from 'fraud detection/deletion, contract/lease cancellation, contract/lease renegotiation, asset sale, grant cancellation, layoffs, project change, and regulatory savings combined.' DOGE emphasized that they are working to upload all this data in an easy-to-understand and fully transparent manner, making clear assumptions that comply with applicable rules and regulations. The department listed contracts from the Federal Procurement Data System (FPDS) publicly released, but noted that FPDS may publish final termination notices with a delay of up to one month, 'FPDS and the numbers published may differ, which are directly from agency contracting officers.' In DOGE's 'Government Efficiency Ranking List,' the Department of Education, General Services Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Labor Department, and Office of Personnel Management ranked in the top five for savings. The institutions that saved the least were the State Department, National Institutes of Health, Department of Transportation, Department of Energy, and Department of Commerce.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 26, 2025 01:05 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://news.ifeng.com/c/8hHTgPENhwd)

**DOGE touts $65B in reported savings, tracks agency efficiency with new dashboard**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has reported $65 billion in estimated savings from cost-cutting procedures, including contract cancellations and workforce reductions. The agency has also launched the 'Agency Efficiency Leaderboard' to track which government agencies are the most efficient. The top agencies with the most savings are the Department of Education, General Services Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Department of Labor, and Office of Personnel Management. On the other hand, the State Department, National Institutes of Health, Department of Transportation, Department of Energy, and the Department of Commerce have reported the least savings. DOGE notes that nearly 40% of canceled contracts did not save any money since the total value was already fully obligated. The agency is working to make the data more transparent and accessible through its website, which also features an interactive 'Wall of Receipts' and tracks agency spending and workforce wages. As stated on the website, 'We are working to upload all of this data in a digestible and fully transparent manner with clear assumptions, consistent with applicable rules and regulations.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 08:07 PM
Source:[WCIV](https://abcnews4.com/news/nation-world/doge-touts-65-billion-in-reported-savings-tracks-agency-efficiency-with-new-dashboard-elon-musk-donald-trump-contracts-savings)

**DOGE Claims $65 Billion in Savings Since Day One**
DOGE, a government efficiency program overseen by Elon Musk, has announced savings of $65 billion, a week after announcing $55 billion in overall savings. The savings came from various sources, including fraud detection, contract cancellations, asset sales, workforce reductions, and regulatory savings. DOGE aims to update its website twice a week with the goal of eventually updating in real-time. The top 10 agencies with the most total savings include the Department of Education, General Services Administration, and Environmental Protection Agency, while the top 10 agencies with the least total savings include the Department of State, National Institutes of Health, and Department of Transportation. DOGE's cuts included ending subscriptions to publications like Politico, Bloomberg, and the Washington Post, which has saved more than $1.5 million and $20 million in leadership training at the Consumer Protection Bureau.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 06:44 PM
Source:[NewsMax](https://www.newsmax.com/finance/streettalk/doge-elon-musk-donald-trump/2025/02/25/id/1200426/)

**Nearly 40% of DOGE's canceled contracts expected to yield no savings**
According to the Trump administration's data, nearly 40% of the 417 contracts canceled by the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) are expected to yield no savings, totaling $478 million. The DOGE, led by Elon Musk, aims to cut and organize federal government spending, estimating $65 billion in savings as of February 24, 2025. The agency attributes the savings to various measures, including fraud detection and contract renegotiations. However, the canceled contracts often have a legal requirement to spend the funds, resulting in no savings. Musk and President Trump will continue their efforts to reduce spending, with federal employees facing uncertainty after Musk's email directive to explain their accomplishments or risk being fired.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 04:21 PM
Source:[FOX 10](https://www.fox10phoenix.com/news/doge-elon-musk-trump-savings-federal-government-employees-canceled-contracts)

**Elon Musk's Ranking of US Government Agencies Based on Economic Savings Raises Concerns**
Billionaire Elon Musk has published a ranking of US government agencies based on their economic savings on the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge) website. The ranking is a competition, with the Department of Education at the top and the Department of State at the bottom. However, experts have criticized the data for errors in calculation, including confusing millions and billions. According to CBS News, Doge misinterpreted the nature of several documents, leading to an overestimation of economic savings by $1.96 billion. Additionally, the budget cuts touted by Elon Musk have raised concerns among experts that they could compromise the US government's ability to manage potential future crises, such as a pandemic. The Doge has, for example, laid off 20 FDA employees, who are responsible for monitoring food and drugs in the US. The Doge website claims that the total estimated savings are $65 billion, which can be attributed to a combination of fraud detection, contract cancellations, renegotiations, asset sales, subsidy cancellations, staff reductions, program changes, and regulatory savings.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 25, 2025 11:02 AM
Source:[BFMTV](https://www.bfmtv.com/economie/international/elon-musk-met-la-pression-aux-administrations-avec-un-classement-de-leurs-economies-realisees_AN-202502250372.html)

**DOGE claims $65B in total estimated savings as 'Agency Efficiency Leaderboard' is launched**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has launched an 'Agency Efficiency Leaderboard' showing government agencies that have saved the most through cost-cutting measures. According to DOGE, the total estimated savings as of Monday are $65 billion. The savings come from a combination of contract cancellations, renegotiations, asset sales, and workforce reductions. DOGE emphasized the need for transparency and has listed contracts that have been posted publicly by the Federal Procurement Data System. The top agencies for savings are the Department of Education, General Services Administration, and Environmental Protection Agency, while the agencies with the least savings are the Department of State, National Institutes of Health, and Department of Transportation. DOGE previously claimed $55 billion in savings, but an error in the data reduced the actual savings to $8.6 billion.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 10:04 AM
Source:[Fox Business](https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/doge-claims-65b-total-estimated-savings-agency-efficiency-leaderboard-launched)

**DOGE says it has saved taxpayers $55 billion so far**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, claims to have saved American taxpayers $55 billion since its inception. The department's 'Wall of Receipts' showcases the cuts made, with the largest being $8 billion from the Department of Homeland Security. The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the Department of Education top the list for 'total contract savings'. DOGE has also defunded various diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives across the government. According to DOGE, the savings come from a combination of fraud detection, contract cancellations, asset sales, and workforce reductions. As DOGE posted on social media, 'Roses are red, violets are blue, Today, DOGE and 10 agencies made 586 wasteful contracts bid adieu!'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 11:09 AM
Source:[americanpress.com](https://www.americanpress.com/2025/02/19/doge-says-it-has-saved-taxpayers-55-billion-so-far/)

**DOGE Says Cost-Cutting Efforts Have Saved An Estimated $55 Billion So Far**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has saved an estimated $55 billion through cost-cutting efforts across federal agencies. The savings came from contract cancellations, asset sales, grant cancellations, workforce reductions, and regulatory savings. DOGE stated that contract cancellations alone accounted for approximately 20% of the overall savings. The top 10 agencies with the highest total contract savings include USAID, the Department of Education, and the Department of Health and Human Services. DOGE has canceled over 200 contracts issued by USAID, including a $45 million DEI scholarship program and a $36 million DEI training contract. DOGE aims to provide real-time updates on its website and has assigned identification codes to Treasury payments to ensure traceability. However, DOGE's efforts have sparked legal challenges from Democratic lawmakers and labor unions, who argue that Musk's access to federal systems is unconstitutional.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:08 PM
Source:[Zero Hedge](https://www.zerohedge.com/political/doge-says-cost-cutting-efforts-have-saved-estimated-55-billion-so-far)

**DOGE says it has saved government $55B so far**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) claims to have saved the government $55 billion through a combination of efforts, including reducing the federal workforce, canceling or renegotiating leases and contracts, selling assets, and making programmatic changes. The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) is listed as the top saving, followed by the Department of Education and the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). DOGE has also cut contracts from various agencies, including the Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Agriculture, and the Environmental Protection Agency. The agency has faced pressure to provide more transparency and is currently facing lawsuits related to its actions. According to DOGE, 'we are working to upload all of this data in a digestible and fully transparent manner with clear assumptions, consistent with applicable rules and regulations.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 02:14 PM
Source:[binghamtonhomepage.com](https://thehill.com/policy/technology/5150593-doe-government-efficiency-savings/)

**DOGE Says Cost-Cutting Efforts Have Saved an Estimated $55 Billion So Far**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has reported that its cost-cutting efforts across several federal agencies have saved an estimated $55 billion as of February 17. Contract cancellations accounted for approximately 20% of the overall savings. The top 10 agencies with the highest total contract savings include the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), the Department of Education, and the Department of Health and Human Services. DOGE has canceled over 200 contracts, including those related to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives. The Treasury Department has also assigned identification codes to track payments, making them compulsory to ensure all payments can be tracked. DOGE's work is expected to be completed by July 4, 2026, as per President Donald Trump's executive order. Trump stated, 'The people voted for major government reform, and that's what people are going to get.' The Government Accountability Office estimates that the U.S. government loses between $233 billion and $521 billion each year due to fraud and improper payments.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 01:41 PM
Source:[www.theepochtimes.com](https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/doge-says-cost-cutting-efforts-have-saved-an-estimated-55-billion-so-far-5811952)

**DOGE Tracker: Department of Government Efficiency Saves Taxpayers $37.69 Billion**
The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has reportedly saved taxpayers $37.69 billion over a period of 506 days, according to their live tracker. This translates to approximately $251.24 per American taxpayer. The DOGE Tracker website claims that this is a significant reduction in federal spending, with the goal of reducing expenses by up to $2 billion by July 4, 2026. The tracker also provides a list of the most effective cost-cutting measures, including the cancellation of 89 education contracts, which resulted in a savings of $881 million. The website presents a 'Leaderboard' ranking the most effective cost-cutting measures, with the top spot going to the USAID cuts of $420 million. According to DOGE Tracker, the department has already saved taxpayers $37.69 billion, which is approximately 424 billion Norwegian kroner, over a period of 506 days. 'DOGE has already saved taxpayers $37.69 billion, which is approximately 424 billion Norwegian kroner, over a period of 506 days,' said the DOGE Tracker. 'This is a significant reduction in federal spending, with the goal of reducing expenses by up to $2 billion by July 4, 2026.' 
Original language: no
Publish date: February 13, 2025 07:42 PM
Source:[inyheter.no](https://inyheter.no/13/02/2025/doge-sparer-allerede-milliarder-for-skattebetalerne1/)

**Trump’s DOGE claims $1 billion saved on cancelled DEI programs**
The US Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), led by Elon Musk, has announced that it has saved over $1 billion by eliminating contracts related to diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) programs. The agency, created by President Donald Trump, aims to reduce federal spending by up to $2 trillion by July 2026. According to DOGE, the savings are due to the elimination of 104 contracts worth over $1.2 billion, as well as a halt to 'unnecessary positions' and 'improper payments to foreign organizations.' Trump has been pushing against DEI programs since taking office, describing them as attempts to 'socially engineer race and gender into every aspect of public and private life.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2025 08:26 AM
Source:[rt.com](https://www.rt.com/news/612005-trumps-doge-claims-billion-saving/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To begin estimating the probability of the Department of State having the highest rank in Least Total Savings on DOGE's Agency Efficiency Leaderboard by April 1, 2025, I must consider historical data on departmental savings and efficiencies. Historically, government departments such as the Department of State have undergone various reforms intended to improve efficiency. However, these reforms typically lead to changes in rankings across multiple departments, rather than consistently placing one department at the bottom. Data from the past suggests that the likelihood of any specific department landing at the top or bottom of such rankings based purely on historical departmental reforms and performance typically ranges from 10% to 15%, given the variety and complexity of influencing factors. Therefore, using a base rate of 15% as a starting point is reasonable.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent State Department Reforms
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The Department of State may have implemented recent reforms, as indicated by various media reports, aimed at improving efficiency which may contribute to higher savings. However, it's possible that these reforms are still being executed and have not yet impacted metrics, conceivably resulting in lower savings rankings temporarily.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Performance Measurement Framework Updates
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If DOGE has revised its performance measurement framework or criteria, it might affect how savings are calculated. An updated framework may favor the Department of State if their operational measures align better with the new framework. This potential alignment could significantly impact rankings.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Government Efficiency Initiatives Across Departments
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Efforts to standardize efficiency improvements across different government departments can smoothen rank differences, making it harder for any one department to be highest in Least Total Savings. This would decrease the probability that the Department of State tops the list.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles confirm that the Department of State is indeed ranked among the agencies with the least total savings on the Efficiency Leaderboard as reported in several sources, including Fox Business and WCIV. The Department of State's position indicates a continuation of their lower performance in savings, aligning with the forecast that they are likely to remain high in least total savings.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: None of the articles suggest a significant shift in the Department of State's savings behavior or reforms that could drastically alter their standing within the given timeframe.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To construct a base rate for the Department of State being ranked highest in Least Total Savings on the Agency Efficiency Leaderboard, I consider historical data on government agency performance in similar ranking systems. Typically, large and complex government departments such as Defense or Health & Human Services are more frequently ranked lower in terms of efficiency due to their size and operational complexity. Historically, the Department of State is smaller and traditionally has less inefficiency compared to these larger entities but still struggles with diplomatic and operational budget efficiencies. Assuming a historical base frequency where the Department of State might not rank at the extremes for efficiency due to moderate-sized operations, an initial probability of 20% is established.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Leadership and Reform Initiatives
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent leadership efforts at the Department of State focusing on reform, as reported by The American Conservative, potentially enhance efficiency operations. This includes initiatives aimed at reducing operational waste and improving diplomatic processes, which could result in substantial savings and thus reduce the likelihood of least savings ranking.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Inherent Complexity of Diplomatic Operations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Diplomatic operations involve complex international relations that naturally incur costs that are challenging to reduce. This intrinsic complexity can limit potential savings, potentially keeping the Department of State in the higher ranks for least savings.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Budgetary Constraints and Political Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Political pressure to showcase governmental fiscal responsibility and budgetary constraints might motivate proactive savings strategies, resulting in potential improvements in efficiency rankings.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple sources, including NewsMax and WCIV, confirm that the Department of State is consistently ranked in the bottom in terms of total savings on the Agency Efficiency Leaderboard, supporting the likelihood of it being highest in 'Least Total Savings.' The repeated mention of the State Department among the least efficient agencies as per DOGE’s rankings solidifies this probability.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There is minimal evidence in the news articles suggesting significant recent improvements in the State Department's savings efforts compared to other departments. Furthermore, skepticism about DOGE's savings methodologies, as raised by BofA analysts and transparency issues highlighted by The Independent, suggests possible inconsistencies or inaccuracies in savings data that might impact rankings.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To determine the initial probability, we consider the frequency with which federal agencies like the Department of State rank highest in least total savings in government efficiency reports. Historically, large bureaucracies such as the Department of State have been reform targets due to their extensive operations and spending. Referring to past similar situations of government reform rankings, large agencies often find it difficult to immediately rank highest in savings due to entrenched processes and large budgets. Therefore, the baseline probability for such a ranking is relatively low, particularly if previous leaderboards have shown a variety of other agencies ranking highest. Assuming these reforms are a novel challenge for many departments, an initial probability estimate might be around 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Departmental Size and Complexity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The Department of State, due to its large size and complexity, is less agile in implementing efficiency reforms quickly, often resulting in savings appearing lower in comparison to smaller agencies.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Historical Trend in Reform Impact
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Historically, large agencies like the Department of State might not top efficiency savings leaderboards as they face significant challenges in reform implementation escalation. This trend suggests such departments might struggle, in the short term, to secure the top spot for least savings.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Specific Focus of Recent Reforms
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The article underscores specific reforms being undertaken within the Department of State. This focused effort, if effectively managed, can lead to incremental yet noteworthy savings improvements as evaluated within this time frame.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles confirm that the Department of State is consistently listed among those with the least savings, according to various reports and data from DOGE. This reinforces the likelihood that it will rank highest in least total savings on April 1, 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Public Sector Reform Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is a broader trend towards improved public sector efficiency across U.S. federal agencies driven by technological advancements and policy reforms. These broader trends would reduce the likelihood of any one department, particularly the State Department after reforms, emerging as the most inefficient in terms of savings.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles confirm that the Department of State is among the agencies with the least total savings and that it is ranked at the bottom of the 'Agency Efficiency Leaderboard' by DOGE. Articles highlighted that the Department of State was specifically mentioned as having achieved minimal savings in comparison to other departments such as the Department of Education and the General Services Administration.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While the articles highlight the Department of State's low savings, some articles criticize DOGE's savings figures as being overstated or containing errors in calculations. Furthermore, challenges to the savings methodology and error-filled reports indicate a lack of confidence in the accuracy of the published leaderboard.

summary: The experts' resolution on whether the Department of State will be ranked highest in Least Total Savings on the Agency Efficiency Leaderboard by April 1, 2025, shows a range of probabilities, with most experts increasing their probability after considering news articles. Initially, probabilities ranged from 5% to 60%, with factors such as departmental complexity, recent reforms, and historical inefficiencies influencing these estimates. In Phase 2, after reviewing news articles confirming the Department of State's low savings ranking, most experts adjusted their probabilities upwards, with final probabilities ranging from 5% to 75%. The experts noted consistent reporting of the Department of State's low savings and inefficiencies, alongside criticisms of DOGE's savings methodologies, reinforcing the likelihood of the Department of State being ranked highest in Least Total Savings.
